title: 115_hr376
content:
The "Shareholder Protection Act of 2017" may be cited as the short title for this Act. Congress finds that corporations make significant political contributions and expenditures that influence elections, decisions are usually made by corporate boards and executives, shareholders historically have not had a way to know or influence political activities, and shareholders and the public have a right to know how corporate funds are spent on political contributions. The text chunk discusses the accountability of corporations to shareholders regarding political contributions and expenditures. It emphasizes the need for corporations to obtain shareholder approval before making such contributions to ensure necessary accountability. SEC. 3. SHAREHOLDER APPROVAL OF CORPORATE POLITICAL ACTIVITY. An amendment to the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 requires shareholder approval for certain political expenditures and mandates disclosure of votes by institutional investors. The section defines 'expenditure for political activities' as independent expenditures, electioneering communications, or payments to trade. The section defines 'expenditure for political activities' as payments to trade associations or organizations described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 that are used for specific purposes, excluding direct lobbying efforts and communications to shareholders and personnel. The term 'issuer' excludes investment companies registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940. Shareholder authorization is required for political expenditures by issuers with registered equity securities. The specific nature of proposed political expenditures for the upcoming fiscal year must be disclosed in proxy solicitations. Issuer must disclose proposed political expenditures for the upcoming fiscal year and obtain shareholder authorization for such expenditures. No expenditure for political activities can be made without majority shareholder vote. The issuer must disclose and obtain shareholder authorization for proposed political expenditures. Violation of the authorization requirement constitutes a breach of fiduciary duty for officers and directors. Those authorizing unauthorized political expenditures are jointly and severally liable for three times the amount spent. Institutional investment managers subject to section 13(f) must disclose their votes on shareholder votes annually, unless already publicly reported. The Commission will issue rules within 6 months to ensure timely disclosure through the EDGAR system. Safe harbor is provided for certain divestment decisions. Safe harbor is provided for institutional investment managers who disclose their decisions to divest from securities of an issuer due to political activities expenditure. No legal action can be taken against the investment manager based solely on this decision. SEC. 4. REQUIRED BOARD VOTE ON CORPORATE EXPENDITURES FOR POLITICAL ACTIVITIES. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include a new section requiring a board vote on corporate expenditures for political activities. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require a vote by the board of directors of an issuer on any expenditure for political activities exceeding $50,000. The Commission will direct national securities exchanges to prohibit listing any equity security of non-compliant issuers. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to require a vote by the board of directors of an issuer on any expenditure for political activities exceeding $50,000. The issuer must make the votes of each board member public within 48 hours. This expenditure will not be considered as coordinated with any candidate or committee under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 now requires a board vote on political expenditures over $50,000, with public disclosure of each member's vote within 48 hours. Expenditures approved by the board will not be considered coordinated with any candidate or committee under the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. SEC. 5. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. Section 13 of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include reporting requirements for political expenditures by issuers with equity securities registered under section 12. The Commission must amend reporting rules to require quarterly reports on political activities expenditures. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include reporting requirements for political expenditures by issuers with registered equity securities. Quarterly reports must include details such as expenditure descriptions, dates, amounts, board votes, candidate names, offices sought, and party affiliations. The Securities Exchange Act of 1934 is amended to include reporting requirements for political expenditures by issuers with registered equity securities. Quarterly reports must include details such as expenditure descriptions, dates, amounts, board votes, candidate names, offices sought, party affiliations, and affiliations of trade associations or organizations exempt from tax under the Internal Revenue Code. The Commission will ensure public availability of these reports through its website and the EDGAR system. The Commission will require issuers to include a summary of political expenditures exceeding $10,000 in their annual reports to shareholders within 180 days of the enactment of the subsection. SEC. 6. REPORTS.

The Securities and Exchange Commission will conduct an annual assessment of issuer compliance with specific sections of the Securities Exchange Act and submit a report to Congress. The Comptroller General of the United States will evaluate the effectiveness of SEC oversight and report to Congress periodically.

SEC. 7. SEVERABILITY. If any provision of this Act or its amendments is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the Act and amendments, as well as their application, will not be affected.
